column2: WOODSIDE, Calif., April 23 (UPI) --Shirley Temple Black, who was Hollywood's best loved child star in the Depression era, starring in such films as "Good Ship Lollipop," "Little Miss Marker", and "Heidi," turned 50 years old today.

Terms of Britain's first public offering in the United States--which the lead underwriter says is the largest issue of bonds sold here by a foreign country, aside from Canada--were set late yesterday afternoon.

NEW ORLEANS, April 26--Modesty has never been one of Gary Player's assets but instead of promoting himself the race-horse breeder from South Africa is letting his recent achievements speak for themselves. With good reason.
WASHINGTON, April 26--The House of Representatives tonight approved a bill that would require lobbyists to disclose many of their activities. The vote was 259 to 140.

ALBANY, April 26--The Senate unanimously passed today a bill abolishing the New York City Board of Water Supply, with Democrats who had expressed doubts about abolition voting for the Republican-sponsored legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 26--The White House announced today that President Carter's national security adviser; Zbigniew Brzezinski, would fly to Peking next month for the highest-level talks with Chinese leaders since last summer.

HACKENSACK, April 26--The judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. WASHINGTON--A new system of shared-cost crop insurance that would combine most of the Government's disaster and drought loss plans was proposed yesterday by Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland.

BOSTON, April 26 (UPI)--The Massachusetts Senate has voted to re-establish the death penalty for some types of murder. The capital punishment bill, approved yesterday, would impose the death penalty for 11 categories of firstdegree murder. The measure included murder-rap, murder of a police officer, murder with extreme brutality and murder for hire.

WASHINGTON, April 26--The Supreme Court ruled today that states cannot bar corporations from spending unlimited amounts of their money to influence the outcome of public referendums, declaring that the Constitution guarantees the corporations freedom of speech just as it does individuals.

WASHINGTON, April 26--The complaint filed today in United States District Court in Atlanta by two Federal agencies sharply contradicts a number of assertions made by Bert Lance, the former Budget Director, in his testimony before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee last fall.

Amid a fanfare of bugles, drums and cannon fire, the Detroit Pistons touched off a new era of basketball salesmanship yesterday in the Silverdome. Actually they hired a coach who is his best public-relations director.

TRENTON, May 1--Governor Byrne announced today a plan to refinance the outstanding debt of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority and thus save the state $111 million over the next 30 years.

Increased sales, mounting production of commercial jets and higher income from other activities were mainly responsible for a 60.2 percent rise in first-quarter earnings of the Boeing Company, T. A. Wilson chairman, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Seattle.

Although in the eyes of some health experts it was too little and too late, the warning issued Wednesday to asbestos workers represents a Federal effort to begin to focus more public attention on a longstanding and widespread occupational health hazard.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Major but gradual changes in retirement policy, including the encouragement of people to go on working long beyond age 65, were recommended today by a leading Social Security expert, A. Haeworth Robertson.

ROME, May 1--Anguish and deepening bitterness are conveyed by the many letters that Aldo Moro, the kidnapped former Prime Minister, has sent to Italian political figures and others since his abduction on March 16.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Supreme Court today agreed to consider whether a ruling by the Securities and Exchange Commission should decide a subsequent civil damage suit between two private parties involving the same factual situation.

NEW ORLEANS, May 1--Ernest N. Morial, the first black ever elected Mayor of this Deep South river city, took office today, asserting, "A new era has begun; the requiem has sounded for the old political order."

CLEVELAND, May 1 (UPI)--Wayne Garland, the Cleveland Indians' pitcher who has been troubled for more than a year with shoulder stiffness, will undergo surgery and miss the rest of the season, the club announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Carter Administration, during Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's visit to Moscow last month to advance a new strategic arms accord, agreed to a vaguely worded provision that would limit future American cooperation on nuclear weapons with allied governments in Western Europe, officials said today.

Ingram.

WASHINGTON, May 2--A majority of the members of a key House committee supported a resolution today opposing the sale of military jet fighters as a "package" to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel.

WASHINGTON, May 2--A large number of agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York have instructed their attorneys to fight any attempts to discipline them for the break-ins, wiretaps and mail openings committed by their squad in the early 1970's, according to agents and attorneys familiar with the case.

WASHINGTON--The active merger trend in Wall Street this decade has not elicited much public reaction from the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Government's regulatory overseer for the nation's securities business.

PARIS, May 2--It is hard these days to find a Frenchman who does not look back with some sympathy to the 1968 student revolt that shook the political foundations of the country and came to be widely viewed as a watershed in the country's modern history.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2--In its first major curriculum change in more than 30 years, the faculty of Harvard University today approved considerably stiffer course requirements for a bachelor's degree.

CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP)--The Cleveland Indians recalled Mike Vail, an outfielder, today from their Portland farm club to fill the roster spot left vacant by Wayne Garland, the injured pitcher. Vail, who was purchased from the New York Mets during spring training, was hitting 367, with four homers and 15 runs batted in at Portland.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2--Mike Battaglia, the program oddsmaker at Churchill Downs, has a problem.

Josef Marais, folk singer, writer and composer, died last Thursday in a Los Angeles hospital, following surgery. He lived in Hollywood. He was 72 years old, and had been active until he entered the hospital.
The Jets drafted yesterday the player they believed was the best college offensive lineman in the United States last year.

ENDLESS strings of club dates and one-nighters--the rockand-roll life for those of less than superstar status--affects performers in several ways. The election yesterday of John H. Gerstenmaier to the new position of vice chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was announced by Charles J. Pilliod Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive officer.

Esmark Inc. announced yesterday that its Swift Company unit was assessed an $861,615 civil judgment in the Federal District Court in Chicago in connection with a suit alleging breach of fiduciary duty, filed by a mutual insurance company it once controlled.

The Treasury sold $2.5 billion of 10year notes yesterday at an average yield of 8.29 percent, the highest rate of return on an issue of intermediate-maturity Government securities since August 1975.

Richard M. Nixon says that the decision to bomb the Hanoi area in Christmas week of 1972 was his most difficult of the whole war, but "it was also one of the most clear cut and necessary ones."

The stock market yesterday suffered its biggest tumble--a drop of 11.35 points in the Dow Jones industrial average-- since its three-week-old rally erupted. Trading was active but ran below Tuesday's pace.

WE ARE dealing with a very timely and ticklish subject this week: spring-cleaning. Spring-cleaning is an old and honorable ritual in which the home, nest, cave or whatever was turned inside out and cleansed and renewed through an intensive scrubbing, polishing and purification that provided a seasonal, psychic and physical rebirth. Spring-cleaning is an ancient urge that comes with soft breezes and clear skies. It is a traditional time of upheaval and renewal.

OF the three United States premieres that made up Tuesday night's program in the 20th-Century Music Series at the Juilliard Theater, Betsy Jolas's "Onze Lieder" for Trumpet and Chamber Orchestra was certainly the most accomplished. WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)--The Senate Human Resources Committee today approved the Humphrey-Hawkins full employment bill, which is designed to cut the nation's unemployment rate to atleast 4 percent by 1983. The measure, approved by a vote of 13 to 2, now goes to the Senate Banking Committee, where hearings are scheduled to begin Monday.

A decade ago, a teacher in one of New York City's academic high schools gave her senior English class a long-range homework assignment to read a novel and be prepared to write an essay of 500 words in class analyzing the motives of the major characters. Students chose works by such authors as Charlotte Bronte, Jane Austen and Ernest Hemingway.

THE Brooklyn Academy of Music began a six-day Old Time Country Music Festival Tuesday night. This is a potentially valuable addition to the city's musical life in several ways, and one hopes it will continue and expand. But the actual opening show left something to be desired.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 3--A federal prosecutor today presented to a jury evidence that was seized in the Washington apartment of a Vietnamese graduate student charged with stealing sensitive documents for Vietnam.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., May 2-- After seven years of confronting all types of petty crimes committed by every sort of criminal, Judge Marbarito C. Garza has finally found the solution to crime in his city--at least in his dreams.

AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, May 3--A precedent-setting rape case that has dragged through a series of courts for nearly four years to become a cause celebre in France concluded here today with sentences ranging from four to six years in prison for three local men.

Following are excerpts from two homework assignments written by seniors who will be graduated from a New York City high school in June. They were selected at random by the students' English teacher, a 17-year veteran of the school system. The essays, she said, were typical of most student writing and should be published to show why so many teachers have become discouraged.

Foreign companies announced a record number of investments in American manufacturing industries in the first quarter, with Britain and West Germany leading the way, according to the Conference Board.
The National Football League's annual draft of college players concluded yesterday with the selection of the last 168 of 334 athletes aspiring for jobs in one of sport's more affluent organizations.

Mr. Haswell, 47 years old, founded the National Association of Railroad Passengers.

Although the President is pressing ahead with plans to phase out the $2.5 billion Clinch River nuclear breeder reactor project at Oak Ridge, Senator James R. Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, said plans for the trip did not call for Mr. Carter to visit the Clinch River project.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)--The Senate today confirmed President Carter's nomination of Robert D. Thorne to run the nation's energy research program. By void vote and without debate, the Senate went along with a recommendation by its Energy Committee that Mr. Thorne get the job, which means he becomes Assistant Secretary for energy techonology. He has held the position on a temporary basis since last October. The job pays $46,500 a year.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)--The Justice Department said over the weekend that there was nothing improper in the Administration's appointment without Senate confirmation last year of four top officials to interim posts in the newly organized Energy Department.

SANDY HOOK, May 21 (AP)--A tugboat crewman presumed dead after he had been thrown overboard when the tug collided with a merchant vessel off the coast here was still missing today, Coast Guard officials said.
New Yorkers kicked up their heels citywide yesterday, highlighting what seemed a mini-season of fetivals compressed into one sunnay weekend.

FROM time to time the New York City Ballet's vast repertory brings back ballets that resemble a plece d'occasion in search of an occasion.

After a yearlong struggle against youth gangs, drug pushers and assaults on teachers, the administration of Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn believes that it has "seized control" of the volatile school.
Victor Gotbaum, the union leader, yesterday called on Governor Carey to "play a more forceful role" in helping to achieve a fiscal package needed for continuing Federal help to New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A Department of Justice task force investigating illegal foreign payments by American corporations is now concentrating on a series of aircraft transactions in the Arab emirates and Bahrain, according to Government and industry sources familiar with the investigation.

NEWARK, May 22--The Manhattan Transit Company agreed today to a oneyear extension of an expired union contract, ending a 52-day strike that had directly affected 20,000 interstate commuters daily and thousands of others forced to ride crowded buses.

Some members of the highly regarded Newark Boys Chorus have become so sought fter tht it is increasingly difficult to get them all together for a concert, but all 34 will be on hand tomorrow night at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall for the premiere of a dramatic cantata by Gian Carlo Menotti, "The Trial of the Gypsy."

Martin Erdmann once had unkind things to say about judges--he called them "whores" and "madams"--and since he was nominated two weeks ago for a Criminal Court judgeship by Mayor Koch, he has had a lot of explaining to do.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 22--People in and around the royal court hope that King Hussein's American bride-to-be will bring fresh ideas and a new dimension to life in this capital, which many consider essentially boring.

WASHINGTON, May 22--In a statement today that the White House helped to draft, Andrew Young, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, played down his differences with President Carter on Congressional restraints on aid to Zaire and other friendly African nations.

LIMA, Peru, May 22--Five people were reported killed today in clashes between demonstrators and the police on the first day of a general strike called to protest Government price increases for food, fuel and transportation.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Robert S. Strauss, the President's chief counselor on inflation, hinted today that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would announce that it was voluntarily adopting restraints on price and pay increases. The company said it would make an announcement tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has asked the Justice Department to defer granting of an antitrust exemption to the nation's hospitals for their "voluntary effort" to hold down costs on the ground that the effort may have an adverse effect on health services.

The Yankees, who have endured more serious injuries to high-priced pitchers than probably any other team --primarily because they own more high-priced pitchers than any other team--gained some degree of consolation yesterday from their latest medical reports.

The Labor Department sued the Western Electric Company yesterday charging that the corporation, in manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company violated Federal age discrimination laws at some of its North Carolina facilities.
A 15-year-old girl was killed at about 7 o'clock last night by a gunshot from an unknown source as she stood chatting with friends on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

The prospective start of legalized gambling later this week in Atlantic City sent gaming stocks sharply higher yesterday as Wall Street's best-winning group. Although some institutions prohibit gambling issues in their portfolios as a matter of policy, traders and other investors bought them avidly.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--The House of Representatives voted 209 to 173 today to grant full trade privileges to Hungary, which would become the fourth Communist-governed state to win favored-nation status from the United States.

Among President Carter's tax reform proposals now before the House Ways and Means Committee is one that would prevent a company from deducting the cost of tickets to sports events as a business expense. In the course of the months of argument over the proposals, sports promoters have been especially active in making known their view that removing the tax deduction would be catastrophic to their profits.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22--It had to happen in this litigious nation. A San Francisco woman has been sued in Small Claims Court here by a San Jose area man for breaking a date.
LONDON, May 22--Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain has been named the first recipient of the Hubert H. Humphrey International Award, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 22--Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.
David R. Berkowitz, who was scheduled to be sentenced yesterday for the six "Son of Sam" murders, battled officers before entering the courtroom, then walked in chanting, "Stacy was a whore."
A five-man committee of partners has been formed to straighten out the tangled finances of the New York Islanders and it does not include Roy Boe, the team's president.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The Supreme Court agreed to-day to decide whether the Federal Reserve System can continue to keep secret for a month its key decisions on monetary policy.

EDWARD ALBEE has just turned 20. Actually he recently celebrated his 50th birthday, but by his own calculation he "began" his life two decades ago when he wrote his first play. In any case, this is an advanced age for America's angriest young playwright, but one which finds him at his busiest and most productive.
Steel production for the week ended May 20 declined to 2.8 million tons, down 0.1 percent from the 2.81 million tons the week before, according to the Iron Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--President Carter sent a supplemental appropriation request for the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration totaling $10 million to Congress today, the White House announced. The money is being requested to implement the community anticrime initiative that Mr. Carter announced earlier as part of his new national urban policy, the White House said.
PEKING, May 22 (Reuters)--The senior Roman Catholic prelate in China, Archbishop Ignatius Pi Shu-shih, died last Tuesday in Shenyang, Roman Catholic sources said today. He was 80 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--Interest rates on Federal Housing Administration mortgage loans will be raised tomorrow to their highest level in two and a half years, the Government announced today.

MOSCOW, May 22--The mother of Anatoly Shcharansky, a dissident who has been held for 14 months on charges of treason, expressed the fear today that the situation of her son had deteriorated since the political trials last week in Moscow and Tbilisi.

ANCHORAGE, May 22 (AP)--Two single-engine planes collided yesterday, killing both pilots as they scanned the spring salmon run for fishermen below, the Federal authorities said. The planes collided near Augustine Island on Cook Inlet, 175 miles southwest of Anchorage. The names of the victims were not released.

The National Science Foundation announced yesterday that its annual Alan T. Waterman Award has been presented to a 34-year-old physicist, Richard A. Muller of the Berkeley Laboratory of the University of California.
This is no time to be a mouse. Scarcely a day goes by without another newspaper report that some poor mouse has been press-ganged into a laboratory and subjected to deadly experiments.

The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust will unveil a new reorganization plan to its 21 bank creditors today that is reported to be mostly cosmetic but that the trust hopes will buy it time to continue the painstakingly slow job of selling assets to pay off creditors.
Franklin Watts, publisher of books for children and adults for more than 36 years, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 10 Waterside Plaza.

ALBANY, May 22--Two of the three key disputes standing in the way of bipartisan approval of New York City's financial legislation were reported to have been resolved today and tonight by negotiators working at the Capitol here.

CAIRO, May 22--The voters of Egypt have overwhelmingly given President Anwar el-Sadat a mandate to carry out his proposals for curtailing political dissent and criticism in the press, the Minister of the Interior, Nabawi Ismail, announced today.

ALBANY, May 22--New York State's prisons are severely overcrowded and the inmate population is continuing to grow, leaving officials struggling to figure out how they will handle the tougher laws and longer sentences being considered by Governor Carey and the Legislature.

Ontario is borrowing $200 million in the United States capital market today, bringing to more than $1.5 billion the volume of Canadian financing done in the public market here so far this year. The province's bonds, which are rated triple-A by both Moody's and Standard Poor's are priced to give investors a yield of 9 3/8 percent.

Hopes for a quick settlement in New York City's labor negotiations were dashed last night when a top union leader emerged from bargaining talks and denounced city officials for making what he described as a "regressive" proposal that, he said, left the two sides further apart than they had been before.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22--The Giant-Dodger rivalry, baseball's most intense historically but stagnant the last six years while the Giants went into eclipse, is flourishing again.

Incendiary devices touched off small fires at the New York metropolitan area's three major airports, and a pipe bomb exploded outside the Justice Department Building in Washington yesterday, but the blasts caused no injuries and only slight damage.

Kenneth D. Kaunda, the President of Zambia, which borders Zaire, said at a news conference here yesterday that "only a political solution" to the conflict in Zaire would prevent another rebel invasion.

BRUSSELS, May 19--Gen. Alexander M. Haig said today that he had been asked by President Carter's Administration to remain in his post as supreme allied commander of Western forces and that he would do so.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 22 (AP)--King Hussein returned to Jordan today after two days of private talks in Saudi Arabia with Crown Prince Fahd. The talks were aimed at rebuilding Arab solidarity after the split caused by Egypt's peace overture to Israel last fall, informed sources said.

TRENTON, May 22--The Casino Control Commission licensed 293 dealers and 30 pit bosses today, and Resorts International Inc. said it would open its gambling casino at Atlantic City Thursday night, a day earlier than had been expected.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--The House voted 388 to 0 today to extend to Sept. 30, 1980, a program offering trial Federal jobs for disabled veterans and Vietnam era veterans with fewer than 14 years of education and to restore eligibility to those who have lost it. The program is now due to expire June 30.

The Great Performers Series sponsored by Lincoln Center will present 39 solo artists and conductors and 11 ensembles in 52 concerts during the 1978-79 season. It is the largest number of events offered in the series since it was started 14 years ago.

ROMEO, Mich., May 22 (UPI)-- Workers at the Ford Motor Company's only tractor plant in North America returned to work today, ending an 11day walkout touched off by a dispute over production standards. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22 (UPI)--Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived here today for a United Nations summit session on disarmament. Mr. Gromyko was the first major official to arrive for the five-week summit, the 10th special session of the General Assembly.

TOKYO, May 22 (UPI)--Japan's automobile production in April totaled 757,277 units, up 7.7 percent from a year ago, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today. WASHINGTON--Students of Democratic power-grabs were impressed last year when Jimmy Carter, in cahoots with Speaker Tip O'Neill, tried to take over the bipartisan Federal Elections Commission.

Small and medium-size manufacturing companies in New York City and Westchester County would be eligible for an electricity rate reduction of up to 20 percent, if a proposal made yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York were adopted by the Public Service Commission.

J.P. Stevens Company, involved in a long, troublesome battle with organized labor, reported yesterday that earnings in both the quarter and six months ended April 29 were down 6.4 percent, while sales for both period, were 4.8 percent higher than the corresponding quarter and half of last year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 24--Yasir Arafat's overall leadership of the Palestinian guerrilla movement was challenged today when five small groups demanded a new leadership that would make decisions collectively.

A proselytizing non-smoker, G. William Miller, two months in office as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has brought down the wrath of his heavy-puffing colleagues by slipping "thank you for not smoking" acrylic signs on tables in the board room and taking away the ash trays.

Tax-exempt bonds yielding more than 7 percent were marketed yesterday as Detroit, one of the handful of major industrial cities that the investment community has accorded second-class citizenship, sold $18.1 million of securities.

The price of beef on the hoof reached a record high of 61.65 cents a pound yesterday in the Sioux City, Iowa, cattle market, while packers paid record prices of 61.50 cents in the Omaha, and Chicago-Joliet receiving centers.

With champagne, violins and a special viewing of the Monet exhibit, New York City welcomed its diplomatic community last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. More than 2,000 guests filled the reception and exhibit halls.

A group of professors at the Harvard Law School has begun collecting endorsements from their colleagues around the country far a statement denouncing the trial of Yuri F. Orlov, the 53-year-old physicist, who was convicted in Moscow last week of "anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda."

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)--President Carter's performance since taking office 16 months ago has been courageous but disappointing because he has failed to deliver on his promises, a study by the Brookings Institution said today.

TBILISI, U.S.S.R., May 24--Friends of a Georgian dissident sentenced last week to five years of imprisonment and banishment said today that most of his nationally televised "confession" had been fabricated by the authorities.

WASHINGTON, May 24--The airline industry, seeking Federal aid, reported today that it might require more than $7 billion to meet the noise-abatement standards of the 1980's, but the chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee challenged the companies to justify their need for Federal help.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)--A strong earthquake shook the Aleutian Islands at 2:17 this morning, but there were no reports of damage, according to the United States Geological Survey. The earthquake, which registered 6.4 on the Richter scale, was felt strongly on Adak. It occurred west of Adak and was measured by the geological survey at Golden, Colo.

TOKYO, May 24--Japan signed a long-term contract here today with Britain for the transport and reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel from 1982 through 1990.

ATHENS, Ga., May 24 (AP)--The Univedsity of California, Los Angeles, beat Southern California and Stanford defeated Southern Methodist in the semifinals of the National Collegiate team tennis championships.

FORDS, May 30--Henry J. Koebel Jr., the only Port Authority of New York and New Jersey police officer ever slain in the line of duty, was eulogized today for offering the "noble gift" of his life while protecting the rights and lives of others. He was then buried in this quiet central New Jersey community where he spent his boyhood and adult life.

The study is not complete, but the results will be produced, Stephen T. Saltz, the Assistant City Solicitor, said.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 7--The responses of black African nations to Western suggestions and support for a continental peacekeeping force have ranged from indignant accusations of neocolonial designs to outright approval.

IC Industries said yesterday that it was going ahead with plans to offer $54 a share--or about $400 million in cash --for Pet Inc., the big food company. It emphasized that the deal did not include Pet's uncompleted takeover of Hardee's Food Systems.

HUNTINGTON, W.Va., June 7 (AP)-- Dozens of Huntington-area high school seniors have received draft notices, but an Army spokesman, Will Drier, said it was just a "malicious prank." He noted that the draft had ended four years ago and suggested that recipients toss the notices into their trash cans.

SALISBURY, Md., June 7 (AP)--Topseeded University of Southern California and Stanford University, seeded second, won today to advance to the final of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Large College tennis championships team competition. U.S.C. defeated University of Florida, seeded fourth, 9-0, while Stanford downed third-seeded U.C.L.A., 6-3.

Bell, his Republican opponent, in the fall campaign.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 7--The Illinois House of Representatives today rejected the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, seriously jeopardizing its chances of adoption nationally before the March 1979 deadline.

BANGKOK, THAILAND, June 7 (AP) --John Everingham, an Australian journalist who swam across the Mekong River underwater two weeks ago to help his woman friend escape from Laos, was arrested today by Thai immigration police.

PALATKA, Fla., June 7 (AP)--The Rev. Cecil Underwood, the minister who baptized Billy Graham, the evangelist, as a Southern Baptist in 1938 died yesterday of an apparent heart attack at his home here.

ROME, June 12--Italian voters in a national referendum yesterday and today strongly endorsed the joint call by the Communist and Christian Democratic parties for maintaining tough law-andorder legislation.

WASHINGTON, June 12--Congressmen from the Northeast and Great Lakes states who have a been able to win some realignment of Federal aid formulas to help their region said today that they wanted an in-depth study of the capital needs of their areas in the hope of cap turing more Federal grants.

SAN DIEGO, June 12--Ninth-inning lightning, which the New Yark Mets enjoyed as a home team last week, struck them as the visiting team tonight when the San Diego Padres scored twice with one out for a 3-2 victory. It was a dismal start for the Mets' eight-game trip through Calinia.

The Bache Group said that it had purchased 489,300 shares of its common stock in a private transaction at $10.25 a share. The Bache Group is a holding company for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, one of the nation's largest brokerage firms.

The proposed merger of W.R. Grace Company and King's Department Stores seemed like a natural. It would have united an extremely successful, far-reaching conglomerate with one of the best-regarded companies among discount stores. But the longer they talked, they more dubious they became.

WASHINGTON, June 12--The General Accounting Office, in a report made public today, joined the rising criticism of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, which it said had failed to act promptly and effectively to protect consumers from hazardous products.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 12 (AP)--Nitric acid fumes today killed a 24-year-old chemical plant worker and another man who had tried to rescue him. Eleven other workers were hospitalized after inhaling the poisonous fumes. The accident occurred at an Engelhard Industries silver nitrate plant here.

It probably was inevitable. With the British bankers and brokers arriving on our shores, could The Economist be far behind? The answer is no. In fact, Clive Greaves is already here, and has been since January.

HAVANA, June 12--A group of students at the University of Havana made it clear to a visiting United States Congressman over the weekend that they passionately supported the African policics of President Fidel Castro.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 12 (Reuters)--Eight employees of the state-run Syrian National Oil Company were found guilty yesterday of accepting $4.7 million in bribes from unidentified foreign companies and sentenced to jail terms ranging from eight months to 15 years.

TOKYO, June 12 (UPI)--Overseas construction projects awarded to 161 major Japanese companies in the fiscal year 1977, which ended March 31, totaled the equivalent of $1.66 billion, down 23 percent from the preceding year, the Construction Ministry reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--While the other guests eat broiled red snapper, the White House will serve Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai of India a special vegetarian meal when he dines with President Carter tomorrow night.

The Farah Manufacturing Company announced that it was seeking to renegotiate terms of a $16 million loan from four lenders.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 12 (AP)-- Thai border policemen repulsed a force of Cambodian soldiers and Thai Communist rebels in northeast Thailand, killing six, when they tried to seize a frontier village over the weekend, police headquarters reported. The police said two Thai villagers were killed and three policemen were wounded during the battle 300 miles northeast of Bangkok.

Clark Center for the Performing Arts will present its fourth annual dance festival at the mall of the City University of New York Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street, from July 5 through Aug. 8. The festival is dedicated this year to the late Thelma Hill, modern dancer and teacher.

In a move to put additional oil and gas operations under Canadian Government control, Petro-Canada, the Government-owned oil company, said early yesterday that it intended to make an offer to acquire Husky Oil Ltd., holder of vast heavy-oil deposits in the provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan.
TEL AVIV, June 12--Sami Esmail a 24-year-old American of Palestinian descent, was sentenced today to 15 months in prison for membership in an Arab guerrilla organization.
Censorship is a dirty word, and nowhere are its implications more apparent, particularly ugly, or debated more energetically than in the television industry.

BERLIN, June 12 (AP)--An East German border guard climbed over a remote rural section of the Berlin wall and fled, armed and in uniform, to West Berlin, the police said today. The escape took place last night along a part of the wall bordering woods and fields in the northwestern district of Spandau, the police said.

WASHINGTON, June 12--In one of their biggest victories in years, the Northern Cheyenne Indians have, at least for the moment, succeeded in blocking the construction of two enormous coal-fired electric power plants 15 miles from their reservation in Montana.

The Polaroid Corporation said that exploratory talks to find a basis for settling its patent-infringement suits against the Eastman Kodak Company had not led to an agreement. Polaroid said it therefore intended to continue to "prosecute vigorously" the actions against Kodak.
WASHINGTON, June 12--The Food and Drug Administration proposed today restrictions on sleeping aids that would end over-the-counter sales of daytime sedatives.
